lines.line_text: WHERE Avon rolls his winding flood,
Whose rich expanse of lawn and wood

stanzas.stanza_text:
WHERE Avon rolls his winding flood,
Where Clifton's summits rise,
Whose rich expanse of lawn and wood
Delights our wondering eyes,

lines.line_text: Raymond, the terror of his foes,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Earl Raymond's castle once arose,
The glory of the plain —
Raymond, the terror of his foes,
Of countless conquests vain.

lines.line_text: Who ne'er the pride of courts assum'd,

stanzas.stanza_text:
There young Matilda's beauty bloom'd
Unenvied, unadmir'd,
Who ne'er the pride of courts assum'd,
Or life of courts desir'd.

lines.line_text: Her brother in these peaceful bowers

stanzas.stanza_text:
Her brother in these peaceful bowers
Had left the lovely maid,
To pass her solitary hours,
While he far distant stray'd —

lines.line_text: Call'd all her sons to arms,
And bore to Judah's distant land

stanzas.stanza_text:
Where Superstition's stern command
Call'd all her sons to arms,
And bore to Judah's distant land
Destruction and alarms —

lines.line_text: In her defence, to seek for fame,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Where pure Religion's injur'd name
Induc'd each hostile lord,
In her defence, to seek for fame,
And wield the vengeful sword.

lines.line_text: While Raymond hop'd, by blood and war,

stanzas.stanza_text:
While Raymond hop'd, by blood and war,
To gain eternal bliss,
Matilda, from dissensions far,
Made sure of happiness,

lines.line_text: For priestcraft ne'er misled her youth,

stanzas.stanza_text:
By gentlest manners, purest truth,
By piety refin'd;
For priestcraft ne'er misled her youth,
Or sway'd her juster mind.

lines.line_text: She knew a dying Saviour bought
The hope which Mercy gave, she sought

stanzas.stanza_text:
She knew a dying Saviour bought
Redemption by his blood:
The hope which Mercy gave, she sought
By mercy to make good.

lines.line_text: Whate'er his faith, she could receive

stanzas.stanza_text:
For she could injuries forgive,
Could weep for fallen foes:
Whate'er his faith, she could receive
The stranger to repose.

lines.line_text: Secure from public noise and strife,
Her thoughts were fix'd on Heaven.

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Mid Clifton's vales, her spotless life
To contemplation given,
Secure from public noise and strife,
Her thoughts were fix'd on Heaven.

lines.line_text: Matilda, shall a breast like thine
Canst thou that holy calm resign,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Matilda, shall a breast like thine
Feel Love's pernicious sway?
Canst thou that holy calm resign,
Through Passion's wilds to stray?

lines.line_text: O let not Love that heart enslave,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Celestial Powers, unite to save
Perfection like your own!
O let not Love that heart enslave,
Where Reason fix'd her throne!

lines.line_text: Ah, fruitless prayer! No pitying power
They rather urge the fateful hour,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Ah, fruitless prayer! No pitying power
Averts Matilda's woes:
They rather urge the fateful hour,
That robs her of repose!

lines.line_text: As near an ancient forest's bounds
The sprightly noise of horns and hounds

stanzas.stanza_text:
As near an ancient forest's bounds
Matilda chanc'd to stray,
The sprightly noise of horns and hounds
Salutes the rising day.

lines.line_text: The virgin sees a glittering train
So light their horses scour the plain,
She scarce their steps can trace.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The virgin sees a glittering train
With shouts attend the chase:
So light their horses scour the plain,
She scarce their steps can trace.

lines.line_text: One she beholds excel the rest
Whose noble air, not splendid vest,

stanzas.stanza_text:
One she beholds excel the rest
In form and manly grace,
Whose noble air, not splendid vest,
Mark'd his distinguish'd race.

lines.line_text: While her pleas'd eyes his form pursu'd,
And fear'd each look the last,

stanzas.stanza_text:
While with delight Matilda view'd
The stranger as he pass'd,
While her pleas'd eyes his form pursu'd,
And fear'd each look the last,

lines.line_text: She sees his horse no longer own
She sees the youthful hunter thrown

stanzas.stanza_text:
She sees his horse no longer own
Obedience to the rein:
She sees the youthful hunter thrown
Extended on the plain!

Though Prudence with contracted mind
Advis'd her to retreat,
With Admiration Pity join'd,
Urg'd on her rapid feet

lines.line_text: To where the lately festive crowd
And beat their breasts, and cry aloud,

stanzas.stanza_text:
To where the lately festive crowd
In tears surround their lord,
And beat their breasts, and cry aloud,
While none relief afford.

lines.line_text: And made her breast their prey.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Matilda with compassion view'd
The stranger as he lay:
Softer sensations soon ensu'd,
And made her breast their prey.

lines.line_text: Where brightest beauty could not warm,

stanzas.stanza_text:
For Pity's unsuspected charm
Has oft seduc'd a heart,
Where brightest beauty could not warm,
Nor wisdom love impart.

lines.line_text: " While yet his spirit lingers here,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Can Sorrow's ineffectual tear,"
She cried, "to life restore?
" While yet his spirit lingers here,
"Celestial aid implore.

"Nor yet supinely wait, that Heaven
" A miracle may grant;
"For seldom aid divine is given
" When human effort's faint.

lines.line_text: "Earl Raymond there, the brave, the good,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Imbosom'd in yon tow'ring wood
" An ancient castle stands:
"Earl Raymond there, the brave, the good,
" Possess'd these happy lands.

lines.line_text: "But since from Britain's shore he's gone,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"But since from Britain's shore he's gone,
" Through Asia's realms to stray,
"These smiling lands I rule alone,
" And all my power obey.

"There men your dying master lead
" With care along the plain;
"For never did Misfortune plead
" At Raymond's gate in vain. "

lines.line_text: Their lord his sad attendants bear

stanzas.stanza_text:
The tear of gratitude sincere
From every eye-lid falls:
Their lord his sad attendants bear
Within the castle's walls.

lines.line_text: But who to thee, incautious fair,

stanzas.stanza_text:
There soon Matilda's tender care
His banish'd sense restor'd:
But who to thee, incautious fair,
Shall now relief afford?

lines.line_text: And, while she thought 'twas Pity's sway,
Love reign'd o'er all her heart.

stanzas.stanza_text:
For treacherous Passion every day
Still deeper sunk the dart;
And, while she thought 'twas Pity's sway,
Love reign'd o'er all her heart.

lines.line_text: At length the fatal truth was known;
How great her joy! How quickly flown,

stanzas.stanza_text:
At length the fatal truth was known;
The stranger own'd his flame:
How great her joy! How quickly flown,
At hearing Osmond's name!

lines.line_text: From her pale cheeks the roses fled,
Pensive she hung her beauteous head,

stanzas.stanza_text:
From her pale cheeks the roses fled,
Tears trembled in her eye;
Pensive she hung her beauteous head,
While sigh succeeded sigh.

lines.line_text: " Shall e'er be join'd with thine.

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Osmond," she cried, "this love withstand;
" To other maids incline:
"Nor fondly hope Matilda's hand
" Shall e'er be join'd with thine.

lines.line_text: "How by thy sire, in prime of life,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Between our race the deadly strife,
" O Osmond! need I tell —
"How by thy sire, in prime of life,
" My hapless father fell?

lines.line_text: "I might — but Raymond ne'er can prove,
" In love or hate, a change.

stanzas.stanza_text:
"And can I swear eternal love
" Where Raymond vows revenge?
"I might — but Raymond ne'er can prove,
" In love or hate, a change.

lines.line_text: "Then cease to feed a fruitless flame
"Nor of that heart the coldness blame —

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Then cease to feed a fruitless flame
" My heart must ne'er return;
"Nor of that heart the coldness blame —
" For thine 'twill ever mourn. "

lines.line_text: " Say not, Matilda, that you prize

stanzas.stanza_text:
"O fatal accents," Osmond cries,
"That blast my promis'd joys!
" Say not, Matilda, that you prize
"The heart your scorn destroys.

lines.line_text: "Yet, if nor Pity's voice, nor Love,
" That breast to feel for me.

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Yet, if nor Pity's voice, nor Love,
" Can change my stern decree,
"Still Piety, perhaps, may move
" That breast to feel for me.

lines.line_text: "We're taught how much by Power divine

stanzas.stanza_text:
"We're taught how much by Power divine
" We need to be forgiven;
"That, if to pardon we decline,
" We lose our promis'd heaven.

"Cold lies my father's honour'd clay:
" With life resentment's fled:
"Shall then Matilda's breast betray
" Fix'd hatred for the dead?

lines.line_text: "Nor in the crime he mourn'd too late

stanzas.stanza_text:
"His closing eyes wept Seward's fate:
" Be then thy pardon won;
"Nor in the crime he mourn'd too late
" Involve his guiltless son. "

lines.line_text: When Passion courts the youthful ear,
Delusion to the heart how dear,

stanzas.stanza_text:
When Passion courts the youthful ear,
How weak is Reason's voice!
Delusion to the heart how dear,
When it confirms its choice!

lines.line_text: And every word from Osmond's tongue

stanzas.stanza_text:
Matilda's passion was so strong,
She wish'd to be deceiv'd;
And every word from Osmond's tongue
Was instantly believ'd.

lines.line_text: But still she hid her fatal flame,
When the sad news to Osmond came,

stanzas.stanza_text:
But still she hid her fatal flame,
Still urg'd a father's death;
When the sad news to Osmond came,
That Edith's parting breath

lines.line_text: In dying accents call'd her son
And said, his presence could alone

stanzas.stanza_text:
In dying accents call'd her son
Her blessing to receive —
And said, his presence could alone
Take terror from the grave.

lines.line_text: His feeling heart in Edith's pain
Her sufferings rack each filial vein,

stanzas.stanza_text:
His feeling heart in Edith's pain
Entirely lost its own;
Her sufferings rack each filial vein,
And all the lover's flown.

lines.line_text: Till he's no more in view.

stanzas.stanza_text:
He press'd Matilda's trembling hands,
And scarcely bid adieu:
Speechless and pale Matilda stands,
Till he's no more in view.

lines.line_text: Then wild through Clifton's tufted groves
Sighs to the gale their hapless loves —
Those sighs but fan the flame.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Then wild through Clifton's tufted groves
She calls on Osmond's name;
Sighs to the gale their hapless loves —
Those sighs but fan the flame.

lines.line_text: "No more his hand my hand shall hold,
" As through these vales I stray!

stanzas.stanza_text:
"No more," she cries, "shall I behold
" His eyes serenely gay!
"No more his hand my hand shall hold,
" As through these vales I stray!

"Osmond, return, my mind from pride
" And prejudice is free:
"Though by thy father Seward died,
" Matilda lives for thee.

"In pity come, my peace restore,
" For thee alone I prize:
"Fruitless entreaties! never more
" Shall Osmond bless these eyes! "

lines.line_text: Twelve times had Cynthia's silver beam
Twelve times had shed on Avon's stream

stanzas.stanza_text:
Twelve times had Cynthia's silver beam
Illumin'd Clifton's height;
Twelve times had shed on Avon's stream
Its inoffensive light:

lines.line_text: Still victim of a hopeless fire,
The roses from her cheeks retire,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Still victim of a hopeless fire,
Matilda pin'd away;
The roses from her cheeks retire,
Her health, her charms decay.

lines.line_text: Her heavy eyes, with fruitless care,
Where, fill'd with anguish and despair,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Her heavy eyes, with fruitless care,
Still turn'd towards the place,
Where, fill'd with anguish and despair,
She last saw Osmond's face.

lines.line_text: At length, upon the opening plain,
She sees a weary, pallid train,

stanzas.stanza_text:
At length, upon the opening plain,
Advancing from afar,
She sees a weary, pallid train,
Sad relics of the war.

lines.line_text: High o'er the rest, his towering form,
That seem'd to brave Misfortune's storm,

stanzas.stanza_text:
High o'er the rest, his towering form,
His firm intrepid air,
That seem'd to brave Misfortune's storm,
Announc'd her brother near.

Through dark affliction's chilling cloud
A ray of pleasure warms:
"Raymond's return'd!" she cries aloud,
And hastes into his arms.

lines.line_text: "Call thee in wars thy youth to spend,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Say, dearest brother, only friend!
" Shall Glory's voice no more
"Call thee in wars thy youth to spend,
" Far from thy native shore?

"Ah! trust not Glory's dangerous charms,
" Who smiles but to betray;
"But, free from tumults and alarms,
" Enjoy life's fleeting day. "

"Belov'd Matilda, never more
" I'll tempt th' inconstant wave;
"No longer quit my native shore,
" Or dearer sister leave.

"For her shall Friendship's milder joys
" Exert their winning power,
"Whilst Hymen's more endearing ties
" Shall gild her latest hour. — "

"No, Raymond, never shall my tongue
" Pronounce the solemn vow;
"Nor e'er, the sacred rites among,
" At Hymen's shrine I'll bow.

lines.line_text: " Still may my mind be free!
"Still every hour, that Heaven can spare,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"From worldly joy, from worldly care,
" Still may my mind be free!
"Still every hour, that Heaven can spare,
" May I devote to thee! "

lines.line_text: "Your hand I've promis'd, and I claim

stanzas.stanza_text:
"A virtuous passion's spotless flame
" Heaven ne'er can disapprove:
"Your hand I've promis'd, and I claim
" As token of your love.

lines.line_text: "Loud o'er the deck the billows roar,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"When near Britannia's rocky shore
" Wild rag'd the bursting storm,
"Loud o'er the deck the billows roar,
" While clouds the skies deform.

lines.line_text: "To turn us from the dangerous land,
" And tempt once more the tide.

stanzas.stanza_text:
"In vain the pilot's trembling hand
" Attempts the stern to guide,
"To turn us from the dangerous land,
" And tempt once more the tide.

lines.line_text: "The winds blew high, the surges swell'd,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"The winds blew high, the surges swell'd,
" Our masts, our cordage lost;
"The shatter'd ship's at length impell'd
" On Devon's hilly coast.

lines.line_text: "The rest tir'd, struggling on the main,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Scarce twenty of my faithful train
" Escape the dangerous wave;
"The rest tir'd, struggling on the main,
" Find there a watery grave.

lines.line_text: "With pain we climb the steepy height,
"When o'er the earth the dewy night

stanzas.stanza_text:
"With pain we climb the steepy height,
" And reach a level mead,
"When o'er the earth the dewy night
" Had cast her sable shade.

lines.line_text: " To wait the approach of day.

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Beneath a lime-tree's sheltering arms
" Our weary limbs we lay;
"And hop'd secure from all alarms,
" To wait the approach of day.

lines.line_text: "But vain our hopes; for, when calm rest
"And lull'd to peace each anxious breast,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"But vain our hopes; for, when calm rest
" Had seal'd each heavy eye,
"And lull'd to peace each anxious breast,
" A cruel band drew nigh.

lines.line_text: "They seiz'd our arms, they bound our hands,
" Of sleep our eyes had clos'd,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"They seiz'd our arms, they bound our hands,
" Whilst fearless all repos'd;
"And soon in everlasting bands
" Of sleep our eyes had clos'd,

lines.line_text: "Endu'd with force to set us free,
" And all our foes to slay.

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Had not, by Mercy's high decree,
" A stranger pass'd that way,
"Endu'd with force to set us free,
" And all our foes to slay.

lines.line_text: "My stubborn soul, which ne'er to power

stanzas.stanza_text:
"My stubborn soul, which ne'er to power
" Or sordid riches bow'd,
"With humblest gratitude that hour
" Its lavish thanks bestow'd.

"Those thanks repeated o'er and o'er,
" My lineage I declar'd,
"And ask'd if Raymond's boundless store
" Such service could reward.

"A crimson blush at Raymond's name
" The stranger's cheeks o'erspread,
"And from his agitated frame
" Its wonted vigour fled.

lines.line_text: " If in vain wealth I could rejoice,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Raymond," he cried, with faltering voice,
"Thy riches I resign:
" If in vain wealth I could rejoice,
"Unnumber'd wealth is mine.

lines.line_text: "But all the wealth the sordid prize,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"But all the wealth the sordid prize,
" Or power the vain desire,
"My towering wishes can despise,
" And higher far aspire.

"If to my pure, unsullied flame
" You would Matilda grant,
"No other riches shall I claim,
" No greater treasure want. "

"Pleas'd with the ardent, generous love,
" Which, scorning meaner views,
"Matilda only could approve,
" Matilda only choose —

"I promis'd, cre to-morrow's sun
" Shall gild the evening tide,
"Thou shouldst, by my entreaties won,
" Consent to be his bride.

lines.line_text: "And cold indeed must be thy heart,
" And blind must be thine eye,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"And cold indeed must be thy heart,
" And blind must be thine eye,
"Whene'er he shall his suit impart,
" Couldst thou that suit deny.

"Then drive, Matilda, from thy brow
" Each vestige of despair;
"A brother's wish, a lover's vow,
" To crown at once prepare. "

lines.line_text: To Raymond's harsh commands the maid
But, sorrowing, low she bow'd her head,

stanzas.stanza_text:
To Raymond's harsh commands the maid
Nor sigh nor tear return'd;
But, sorrowing, low she bow'd her head,
And silently she mourn'd.

lines.line_text: Now Cynthia o'er the azure sky
Around the world light visions fly,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now Cynthia o'er the azure sky
Her starry mantle throws;
Around the world light visions fly,
To soften human woes.

lines.line_text: Led by soft slumber, kindly came

stanzas.stanza_text:
But no delusive, flattering dream,
Which grants a short relief,
Led by soft slumber, kindly came
To sooth Matilda's grief.

lines.line_text: Prest by a weight of care,
No more her weak, distemper'd mind

stanzas.stanza_text:
Supinely on her couch reclin'd,
Prest by a weight of care,
No more her weak, distemper'd mind
Could comfort find in prayer.

lines.line_text: Firm in their cause that heart can bleed,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Affection, Duty, strongly plead
Her constant heart to move:
Firm in their cause that heart can bleed,
But cannot cease to love.

lines.line_text: Now in the east with blushing pride
And Health, with Labour by her side,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now in the east with blushing pride
The purple morning rose,
And Health, with Labour by her side,
Starts from a light repose.

lines.line_text: Despair sits lowering in her eyes,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Matilda from her chamber hies,
All spiritless and weak;
Despair sits lowering in her eyes,
And sickens on her cheek.

lines.line_text: The mead and garden's rich perfume
But through the forest's awful gloom

stanzas.stanza_text:
The mead and garden's rich perfume
No more her steps delay,
But through the forest's awful gloom
She bends her devious way.

lines.line_text: There, as immers'd in grief profound

stanzas.stanza_text:
There, as immers'd in grief profound
Through pathless wilds she treads,
The deadly nightshade all around
Its baneful berries spreads.

lines.line_text: And Faith with Reason now subdued,

stanzas.stanza_text:
The fatal plant Matilda view'd,
Then touch'd with trembling hand;
And Faith with Reason now subdued,
Left Grief entire command.

lines.line_text: Now her pale lips the berries stain,
And now through every freezing vein

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now her pale lips the berries stain,
Which eagerly she rends;
And now through every freezing vein
Their poisonous juice descends.

lines.line_text: Raymond, who long with fruitless haste
Now sees her in the desert waste,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Raymond, who long with fruitless haste
Sought the devoted fair,
Now sees her in the desert waste,
Reclin'd with pensive air.

"Matilda, why this long delay?
" Why these dejected eyes?
"Why this disorder'd, loose array?
" Thy lover waits, "he cries.

"Raymond, I haste," the maid replied,
"Thy promise to fulfil,
" And follow wheresoe'er you guide,
"Obedient to your will."

lines.line_text: To where an ancient chapel stood,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now from the solitary wood
With rapid steps they turn'd,
To where an ancient chapel stood,
Where Seward lay inurn'd.

lines.line_text: And beating breasts, they paus'd awhile,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Before the venerable pile,
With reverential fear
And beating breasts, they paus'd awhile,
And shed a filial tear.

Now entering with averted eyes,
This hated lord to meet,
Matilda sees with wild surprise
Her Osmond at her feet.

lines.line_text: Just then the poison's subtle power
She sinks upon the marble floor,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Just then the poison's subtle power
Invades its trembling prey;
She sinks upon the marble floor,
Cold as her kindred clay.

lines.line_text: And sees from all mat charm'd his sight

stanzas.stanza_text:
Osmond, with anguish and affright,
Bends o'er the dying maid,
And sees from all mat charm'd his sight
The living lustre fade.

lines.line_text: " O bless him with a smile;
"With one kind look, ere yet he falls,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Matilda, 'tis thy Osmond calls,
" O bless him with a smile;
"With one kind look, ere yet he falls,
" His misery beguile. "

lines.line_text: At his lov'd name she op'd her eyes,

stanzas.stanza_text:
At his lov'd name she op'd her eyes,
And rais'd her languid head;
"Osmond, dear youth!" she faintly cries,
"I hasten to the dead.

lines.line_text: " And calls me to the tomb.

stanzas.stanza_text:
"A poison on my vitals preys,
" And withers all my bloom;
"The rapid flood of life delays,
" And calls me to the tomb.

lines.line_text: "Yet, Osmond, though we soon must part —
"To the last gasp this lingering heart

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Yet, Osmond, though we soon must part —
" From other contracts free,
"To the last gasp this lingering heart
" Shall fondly dwell with thee. "

lines.line_text: More had she said, but envious Death
Faint, and more faint, her struggling breath

stanzas.stanza_text:
More had she said, but envious Death
Assum'd his iron sway:
Faint, and more faint, her struggling breath
Entirely dies away.

lines.line_text: Whilst Raymond, fill'd with vain remorse,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Whilst Raymond, fill'd with vain remorse,
To view his victim fears,
Osmond bedews her senseless corse
With unavailing tears.

lines.line_text: " And join thee in the grave.

stanzas.stanza_text:
He cries, "Belov'd Matilda, wait,
" Nor yet thy Osmond leave —
"Who hastens to partake thy fate,
" And join thee in the grave.

lines.line_text: "You hop'd, when life's sad race was run,

stanzas.stanza_text:
"Now, Edith, to thy hapless son
" Those mournful duties give,
"You hop'd, when life's sad race was run,
" From him you might receive.

"May piety thy woes assuage!
" Nor let my early doom
"Depress thy weak, declining age
" Untimely to the tomb! "

While duty and afffection warm
Thus his last thoughts inspir'd,
He press'd Matilda's lifeless form,
And, bow'd by grief, expir'd.
